  "article_text": [
    "in ( * ? ? ? * theorem  4.3 ) , adams proved that the fundamental group of a finite volume hyperbolic manifold is generated by two parabolic transformations if and only if it is homeomorphic to the complement of a @xmath0-bridge link @xmath1 which is not a torus link .",
    "this refines the result of boileau and zimmermann ( * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary  3.3 ) that a link in @xmath2 is a @xmath0-bridge link if and only if its link group is generated by two meridians .",
    "adams also proved that any parabolic generating pair of a hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge link consists of meridians .",
    "this means that any such pair is represented by an arc properly embedded in the exterior @xmath3 , together with a pair of meridional loops on @xmath4 passing through the endpoints of the arc .",
    "the meridian pair represented by the upper ( resp .",
    ", lower ) tunnel forms a parabolic generating pair , and is called the _ upper meridian pair _ ( resp . , the _ lower meridian pair _ ) .",
    "he also proved that each hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge link group admits only finitely many distinct parabolic generating pairs up to conjugacy ( * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary  4.1 ) and moreover that , for the figure - eight knot group , the upper and lower meridian pairs are the only parabolic generating pairs up to conjugacy ( * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary  4.6 ) ) .",
    "these results were generalized to all @xmath0-bridge links by agol @xcite .",
    "in fact , he classified all two parabolic generator kleinian groups and their parabolic generating pairs . to this end",
    ", he proved that for any properly embedded arc in @xmath3 which is not properly homotopic to the upper tunnel nor the lower tunnel , the subgroup of the link group of @xmath1 generated by the meridian pair represented by the arc is a free group , by using the checkerboard surfaces and klein - maskit combination theorem .",
    "the purpose of this paper , however , is to give an alternative proof of this result for genus - one hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge knots by using small cancellation theory and a geometric observation suggested by michel boileau to us @xcite .",
    "recall that a @xmath0-bridge knot has genus one if and only if it is equivalent to @xmath1 with @xmath5:= \\displaystyle \\frac 1{\\displaystyle 2m\\pm \\frac 1{\\displaystyle 2n}},\\ ] ] where @xmath6 and @xmath7 are positive integers .",
    "we now describe our strategy .",
    "it is well - known that any parabolic generating pair of a @xmath0-bridge link group @xmath8 determines a _ strong inversion _ , @xmath9 , of the link @xmath1 , i.e. , an orientation - preserving involution of @xmath2 preserving @xmath1 setwise such that the fixed point set @xmath10 is a circle intersecting each component of @xmath1 in two points .",
    "the key observation , which boileau brought to us , is that the parabolic generating pair is represented by an arc component of @xmath11 ( see proposition  [ prop : strong - involution_1 ] ) .",
    "every @xmath0-bridge link admits a diagram which has a @xmath12-symmetry as in figure  [ fig.long_meridian_pair ] .",
    "let @xmath13 ( resp . ,",
    "@xmath14 ) be the @xmath15-rotations about the horizontal ( resp . , vertical ) axis in the projection plane . if the slope @xmath16 satisfies the condition @xmath17 , then any strong inversion @xmath9 of @xmath1 is strongly equivalent to one of the two standard inversions @xmath13 and @xmath14 , namely @xmath9 is conjugate to @xmath13 or @xmath14 by a homeomorphism of @xmath18 which is pairwise isotopic to the identity ( cf .",
    "* proposition  3.6 ) and the proof of corollary  [ prop : strong - involution_2 ] ) .",
    "we may assume that @xmath19 contains the upper tunnel , @xmath20 , and @xmath21 contains the lower tunnel , @xmath22 .",
    "( see @xcite for interesting related results . )",
    "now suppose further that @xmath1 is a knot , and let @xmath23 be the component of @xmath24 different from @xmath25 .",
    "we call the meridian pairs represented by @xmath26 and @xmath27 , respectively , the _ long upper meridian pair _ and the _ long lower meridian pair _",
    "( see figure  [ fig.long_meridian_pair ] ) .",
    "the main ingredient of this paper is a combinatorial proof of the following theorem based on small cancellation theory .",
    "the long upper meridian pair @xmath28 of @xmath1 with @xmath29 $ ] . to be precise , @xmath30 ( resp . , @xmath31 )",
    "is represented by the left ( resp .",
    ", right ) lasso together with an almost vertical line joining the end point of the lasso with the base point of @xmath3 .",
    "note that the upper tunnel is the short subarc , with both endpoints in @xmath1 , of the horizontal central line in the projection plane . ]",
    "[ thm : main_theorem ] let @xmath32 $ ] , where @xmath6 and @xmath7 are positive integers , and let @xmath33 be the long upper meridian pair or the long lower meridian pair for @xmath1 .",
    "then the subgroup of @xmath8 generated by @xmath30 and @xmath31 is a free group .",
    "since there is a homeomorphism from @xmath34 with @xmath32 $ ] to @xmath35 with @xmath36 $ ] , which maps the long lower meridian pair of @xmath1 to the long upper meridian pair of @xmath37 , it is enough to prove the theorem only for the long upper meridian pair .",
    "thus throughout the remainder of this paper , @xmath33 denotes the long upper meridian pair for @xmath1 as illustrated in figure  [ fig.long_meridian_pair ] .    in the special case",
    "when @xmath38 $ ] , we have yet another equivalence class of strong inversions , which is represented by the strong inversion , @xmath39 , illustrated by figure  [ fig.additional-inversion ] ( see also figure  [ fig.additional-inversion2 ] and ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  3.6 ) ) .",
    "additional symmetry of @xmath1 for @xmath38 $ ] ( @xmath40 ) .",
    "@xmath41 , where @xmath42-rotation about @xmath43-rotation about @xmath44 , @xmath45-rotation around @xmath46 , and @xmath47-rotation around @xmath48 . ]",
    "[ thm : main_theorem_2 ] let @xmath38 $ ] , where @xmath6 is an integer @xmath49 , and let @xmath39 be the strong inversion of @xmath18 as in the above .",
    "then , for each of the arc components of @xmath50 , the subgroup of @xmath8 generated by the meridian pair represented by the arc is a proper subgroup of @xmath8 .    in fact , it is not difficult to extend theorem  [ thm : main_theorem_2 ] to all hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge knots @xmath51 with @xmath52 .",
    "we also believe that theorem  [ thm : main_theorem ] can be extended to all hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge links by a similar method , but the arguments would become much more complicated .",
    "these two theorems enable us to recover a special case of agol s result  @xcite .",
    "[ cor : agol - special ] let @xmath1 be a genus - one hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge knot , namely @xmath53 $ ] with @xmath54 or @xmath55 $ ] with @xmath54 and @xmath56 . then the upper and lower meridian pairs are the only parabolic generating pairs of the knot group of @xmath1 up to equivalence .    for the precise definition of the equivalence relation in the above corollary , see the first paragraph of section  [ sec : strong - inversion ] .",
    "together with the result of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary  1.3 ) on epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge knot groups and the characterization by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* main theorem  2.4 ) of upper meridian pair preserving epimorphisms between @xmath0-bridge link groups , the above corollary implies the following theorem .",
    "[ thm : cor - epimorohism ] let @xmath1 be a genus - one hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge knot and @xmath57 be a @xmath0-bridge knot . then there is an epimorphism from @xmath58 onto @xmath8 if and only if @xmath59 or @xmath60 belongs to ( i ) the @xmath61-orbit of @xmath62 or @xmath63 or ( ii ) the @xmath64-orbit of @xmath65 or @xmath63 . here",
    "( a ) @xmath61 ( resp . , @xmath64 ) is the subgroup of the automorphism group of the farey tessellation generated by the reflections in the farey edges with endpoints @xmath63 or @xmath62 ( resp . , @xmath65 ) , and ( b ) @xmath66 , where @xmath67 ; @xmath68 and @xmath69 are relatively prime integers such that @xmath16 .    at the end of the introduction",
    ", we would like to point out that if we remove the condition that generating pairs consist of parabolic elements , then it is proved by heusener and porti  @xcite that every hyperbolic knot admits infinitely many generating pairs up to nielsen equivalence .",
    "moreover , the same conclusion for torus knots , especially non - hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge knots , had been proved by zieschang  @xcite .",
    "the authors would like thank michel boileau for fruitful discussions .",
    "they would also like to thank colin adams and ian agol for their encouragement .",
    "let @xmath70 be a link in @xmath2 and @xmath71 the exterior of @xmath70 , namely the complement of an open regular neighborhood of @xmath70 . an essential simple loop in @xmath72",
    "is called a _ meridian _ if it bounds a disk on the ( closed ) regular neighborhood of @xmath70 .",
    "an element of the link group @xmath73 which is freely homotopic to a meridian is also called a _ meridian_. by a _",
    "meridian pair _ of @xmath70 , we mean an unordered pair @xmath74 of meridians of @xmath75 .",
    "two meridian pairs @xmath74 and @xmath76 are said to be _ equivalent _ if @xmath76 is equal to @xmath77 for some @xmath78 up to simultaneous conjugacy .",
    "note that there is a bijective correspondence between the set of meridian pairs up to equivalence and the set of arcs properly embedded in @xmath71 up to proper homotopy . here",
    "a proper arc @xmath46 in @xmath71 corresponds to a meridian par @xmath79 which is obtained as follows .",
    "pick an interior point , @xmath69 , in @xmath46 , and divide @xmath46 into two subarcs @xmath80 and @xmath81 such that @xmath82 . for @xmath83 ,",
    "let @xmath84 be a meridian passing through the end point of @xmath85 in @xmath72 .",
    "let @xmath86 be an arc in @xmath71 joining @xmath69 with the base point of @xmath71 .",
    "then the pair of based loops @xmath87 gives the meridian pair @xmath74 corresponding to the arc @xmath46 .",
    "if @xmath70 is hyperbolic , then a meridian pair @xmath74 is identified with a pair of parabolic transformations of the hyperbolic @xmath88-space .",
    "we are interested only in the case where @xmath74 generate a non - elementary kleinian group , namely the case where the parabolic fixed points of @xmath89 and @xmath90 are not identical .",
    "then the geodesic joining the parabolic fixed points of @xmath89 and @xmath90 descends to a proper geodesic in the hyperbolic manifold @xmath91 and hence determines a proper arc in @xmath71 , where we identify @xmath71 with the complement of an open cusp neighborhoods . by the correspondence between the fundamental group and the covering transformation group ,",
    "we see that this arc corresponds to the meridian pair @xmath79 .",
    "boileau  @xcite informed us of the following fact , which had been observed by adams  @xcite .",
    "[ prop : strong - involution_1 ] let @xmath1 be a hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge link , and let @xmath74 be a parabolic generating pair of the link group @xmath8 . then there is a strong inversion @xmath9 of @xmath1 such that @xmath92 and that @xmath74 is a meridian pair corresponding to an arc component of @xmath11 .",
    "here @xmath93 denotes the automorphism of @xmath8 induced by @xmath9 .",
    "let @xmath1 be a hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge link , and let @xmath74 be a parabolic generating pair .",
    "then , by assumption , @xmath89 and @xmath90 are identified with parabolic transformations . since @xmath74 generates non - elementary group @xmath8 , @xmath89 and @xmath90",
    "have distinct parabolic fixed points .",
    "let @xmath94 be the order @xmath0 elliptic transformation whose axis is the geodesic , @xmath95 , joining the two parabolic fixed points",
    ". then @xmath96 and @xmath97 ( cf .",
    "* section  5.4 ) ) and therefore @xmath94 descends to an orientation - preserving involution , @xmath9 , of @xmath98 , such that the restriction of @xmath9 to @xmath4 is a hyper - elliptic involution .",
    "thus @xmath9 extends to a strong inversion of @xmath1 , which we continue to denote by the same symbol @xmath9 .",
    "now recall the result ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  4.3 ) that @xmath74 is a meridian pair .",
    "thus by the observation made before this proposition , we obtain the desired result .",

    ", we can express @xmath139 , @xmath158 , @xmath30 and @xmath31 as words in @xmath125 .",
    "[ con : words ] in the remainder of this paper , we use the symbols @xmath139 , @xmath158 , @xmath30 and @xmath31 to denote the _ reduced _ words in @xmath125 obtained as in the above .    for the definition of reduced words , see section  [ sec : s - sequence ] below .",
    "we first recall basic terminology in combinatorial group theory and the definition of @xmath159-sequences and cyclic @xmath159-sequences introduced in ( * ? ? ? * section  4 ) .",
    "let @xmath160 be a set . by a _ word _ in @xmath160 ,",
    "we mean a finite sequence @xmath161 where @xmath162 and @xmath163 .",
    "we call @xmath164 and @xmath165 the _ initial letter _ and _ terminal letter _ of the word , respectively . for two words",
    "@xmath166 in @xmath160 , by @xmath167 we denote the _ visual equality _ of @xmath168 and @xmath169 , meaning that if @xmath170 and @xmath171 ( @xmath172 ; @xmath173 ) , then @xmath174 and @xmath175 and @xmath176 for each @xmath177",
    ". the length of a word @xmath169 is denoted by @xmath178 .",
    "a word @xmath169 in @xmath160 is said to be _ reduced _ if @xmath169 does not contain @xmath179 or @xmath180 for any @xmath181 .",
    "a _ cyclic word _ is defined to be the set of all cyclic permutations of a cyclically reduced word . by @xmath182",
    "we denote the cyclic word associated with a cyclically reduced word @xmath169 . also by @xmath183 we mean the _ visual equality _ of two cyclic words @xmath184 and @xmath182 .",
    "in fact , @xmath183 if and only if @xmath169 is visually a cyclic shift of @xmath168 .",
    "[ def : alternating ]    \\(1 ) let @xmath169 be a reduced word in @xmath125 .",
    "decompose @xmath169 into @xmath185 where , for each @xmath186 , all letters in @xmath187 have positive ( resp . , negative )",
    "exponents , and all letters in @xmath188 have negative ( resp .",
    ", positive ) exponents",
    ". then the sequence of positive integers @xmath189 is called the _ @xmath159-sequence of @xmath169_.    \\(2 ) let @xmath182 be a cyclic word in @xmath190 .",
    "decompose @xmath182 into @xmath191 where all letters in @xmath187 have positive ( resp . , negative )",
    "exponents , and all letters in @xmath188 have negative ( resp . , positive ) exponents ( taking subindices modulo @xmath138 )",
    ". then the _ cyclic _ sequence of positive integers @xmath192 is called the _ cyclic @xmath159-sequence of @xmath182_. here the double parentheses denote that the sequence is considered modulo cyclic permutations .",
    "\\(3 ) a reduced word @xmath169 in @xmath125 is said to be _ alternating _ if @xmath193 and @xmath194 appear in @xmath169 alternately , i.e. , neither @xmath195 nor @xmath196 appears in @xmath169 . a cyclic word @xmath182",
    "is said to be _ alternating _ if all cyclic permutations of @xmath169 are alternating . in the latter case , we also say that @xmath169 is _ cyclically alternating_.     ", we can see @xmath426 hence @xmath427 ends with @xmath428 or @xmath429 for some @xmath430 according to whether @xmath431 or not .",

    "the proof of theorem  [ thm : main_theorem ] is now completed .",
    "in this section , we prove theorem  [ thm : main_theorem_2 ] by using the homology of the double branched covering , @xmath469 , of @xmath2 branched over @xmath1 and the @xmath15-orbifold group @xmath470 introduced by boileau and zimmermann  @xcite .    as in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section  2 ) , we regard @xmath18 as the union of two rational tangles @xmath471 and @xmath472 of slopes @xmath63 and @xmath62 . here the common boundary @xmath473 is identified with the conway sphere @xmath474 , where @xmath475 is the group of isometries of the euclidean plane @xmath346 generated by the @xmath15-rotations around the points in the lattice @xmath476 . for each rational number @xmath477 , a line of slope @xmath478 in @xmath479 projects to an essential simple loop , denoted by @xmath480 , in @xmath481 .",
    "similarly , a line of slope @xmath478 in @xmath346 passing through a point @xmath476 determines an essential simple proper arc , denoted by @xmath482 , in @xmath481 .",
    "the rational number @xmath478 is called the _ slope _ of @xmath480 and @xmath482 . by the definition of the rational tangles , the loops @xmath483 and",
    "@xmath484 bound disks in @xmath485 and @xmath486 , respectively .",
    "the double branched covering @xmath469 of @xmath18 is the union of the solid tori @xmath487 and @xmath488 which are obtained as the double branched coverings of @xmath471 and @xmath472 , respectively .",
    "let @xmath489 and @xmath490 be lifts in @xmath491 of the simple loops @xmath492 and @xmath483 , respectively . then @xmath489 and @xmath490 form the meridian and the longitude of @xmath487 . similarly",
    "a lift @xmath493 of @xmath484 in @xmath494 is a meridian of @xmath488 .",
    "thus @xmath495 $ ] and @xmath496 $ ] are the zero elements of @xmath497 and @xmath498 , respectively . since @xmath496=p[\\tilde\\alpha_0]+q[\\tilde\\alpha_{\\infty}]$ ] in @xmath499 , where @xmath16 , we have @xmath500\\rangle \\cong { \\mathbb{z}}/p{\\mathbb{z}}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    recall the @xmath15-orbifold group @xmath470 of the knot @xmath1 , which is defined as the quotient of the knot group @xmath8 by the normal subgroup normally generated by the square of meridians ( see @xcite ) .",
    "then @xmath470 is the semidirect product @xmath501 and so it is isomorphic to the dihedral group of order @xmath502 .    ]",
    "we prove theorem  [ thm : main_theorem_2 ] by showing that the images in @xmath470 of the groups generated by the meridian pairs in the theorem is a proper subgroup of @xmath470 .",
    "let @xmath62 be the rational number @xmath503=[2m-1,1,2m-1]=\\frac{2m}{4m^2 - 1}=\\frac{2m}{(2m+1)(2m-1)}.\\ ] ] observe that the involution @xmath39 in figure  [ fig.additional-inversion ] is equivalent to the involution in figure  [ fig.additional-inversion2](a ) .",
    "let @xmath504 and @xmath505 be the components of @xmath506 where @xmath507 , as illustrated in figure  [ fig.additional-inversion2](a ) .",
    "we can observe that the arcs @xmath504 and @xmath505 are the proper essential arcs in the conway sphere @xmath508 of slopes @xmath509 and @xmath510 , respectively .",
    "in fact , the involution @xmath39 preserves @xmath508 and the involution of the farey tessellation induced by the restriction of @xmath511 is the reflection in the geodesic joining @xmath512 and @xmath513 ( see figure  [ fig.additional-inversion2](b ) ) .    for @xmath83 ,",
    "let @xmath514 be the meridian pair represented by the proper arc @xmath515 .",
    "then , by the above observation , the subgroup @xmath516 of @xmath8 is equal to @xmath517 , where @xmath518 is an element of @xmath8 represented by the simple loop @xmath518 in @xmath508 of slope @xmath519 .",
    "note that @xmath520=(2m-1)[\\tilde\\alpha_0]+1[\\tilde\\alpha_{\\infty } ] = ( 2m-1)[\\tilde\\alpha_0 ] \\in h_1(m(k(r ) ) \\cong { \\mathbb{z}}/(4m^2 - 1){\\mathbb{z}}.\\ ] ] thus the subgroup @xmath521\\rangle$ ] of @xmath522 has order @xmath390 and so it is a proper subgroup of @xmath522 .",
    "similarly , the subgroup @xmath523\\rangle$ ] of @xmath522 has order @xmath394 and so it is a proper subgroup of @xmath522 .    on the other hand ,",
    "the image of @xmath524 in @xmath470 is the semidirect product @xmath525\\rangle   \\rtimes { \\mathbb{z}}/2{\\mathbb{z}}$ ] .",
    "hence , it is a proper subgroup of @xmath470 , and therefore @xmath516 is a proper subgroup of @xmath8 for each @xmath83 .",
    "this completes the proof of theorem  [ thm : main_theorem_2 ] .",
    "\\(1 ) we can show that @xmath526 is a free group by an argument parallel to the proof of theorem  [ thm : main_theorem ] .",
    "however , our method does not work for the subgroup @xmath527 .",
    "\\(2 ) theorem  [ thm : main_theorem_2 ] can be easily extended to every @xmath0-bridge knot @xmath1 with @xmath16 such that @xmath52 .",
    "in fact , we can see that , for the additional strong inversion @xmath39 , the components , @xmath504 and @xmath505 , of @xmath50 are proper essential arcs of slopes @xmath528 and @xmath529 , where @xmath530 and both @xmath416 and @xmath417 are greater than @xmath381 .",
    "thus we can see that the subgroup of @xmath470 generated by the meridian pair represented by @xmath515 is a proper subgroup for @xmath83 .",
    "immediate from theorems  [ thm : main_theorem ] and  [ thm : main_theorem_2 ] and corollary  [ prop : strong - involution_2 ] .",
    "the if part follows from the if part of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* main theorem  2.4 ) ( which is essentially equivalent to ( * ? ? ? * theorem  1.1 ) ) and the fact that @xmath8 is isomorphic to @xmath531 .",
    "so we prove the only if part .",
    "let @xmath532 be an epimorphism between @xmath0-bridge knot groups satisfying the assumption of the theorem . by ( * ?",
    "* corollary  1.3 ) , @xmath533 maps the upper meridian pair @xmath534 of @xmath58 to peripheral elements of @xmath8 .",
    "thus @xmath535 is a parabolic generating pair and hence by corollary  [ prop : strong - involution_2 ] , it is either ( i ) the upper or lower meridian pair , ( ii ) the long upper or long lower meridian pair , or ( iii ) isomorphic to the upper or lower exceptional pair .",
    "however , theorems  [ thm : main_theorem ] and  [ thm : main_theorem_2 ] prohibit the last two possibilities , and hence @xmath533 maps the upper meridian pair of @xmath58 to the upper or lower meridian pair of @xmath8 .",
    "suppose first that @xmath533 maps the upper meridian pair of @xmath58 to the upper meridian pair of @xmath8 .",
    "then @xmath59 or @xmath60 belongs to the @xmath61-orbit of @xmath62 or @xmath63 by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* main theorem  2.4 ) .",
    "suppose next that @xmath533 maps the upper meridian pair of @xmath58 to the lower meridian pair of @xmath8 .",
    "note that there is an isomorphism from @xmath8 to @xmath531 which maps the lower meridian pair of @xmath8 to the upper meridian pair of @xmath531 .",
    "thus the composition of @xmath533 and this isomorphism is an epimorphism from @xmath58 to @xmath531 which maps the upper meridian pair of @xmath58 to that of @xmath531 .",
    "hence , by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* main theorem  2.4 ) , @xmath59 or @xmath60 belongs to the @xmath64-orbit of @xmath65 or @xmath63 .",
    "this completes the proof of theorem  [ thm : cor - epimorohism ] .",
    "f.  bonahon and l.  siebenmann , _ new geometric splittings of classical knots , and the classification and symmetries of arborescent knots _ , preprint , available from http://www-bcf.usc.edu/  fbonahon / research / preprints / preprints.html"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we show that any parabolic generating pair of a genus - one hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge knot group is equivalent to the upper or lower meridian pair . as an application </S>",
    "<S> , we obtain a complete classification of the epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge knot groups to genus - one hyperbolic @xmath0-bridge knot groups . </S>"
  ]
}
